conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, and F, coming into contact due to gravity.
Object A is positioned above block C and block D, while object B is positioned above block E and block F.
After A and B are set down, each will come to rest on the upper faces of the blocks below (C, D, E, F).
The cloths/objects stop moving once the downward gravitational pull is balanced by the upward supporting (normal) forces from the blocks.
The blocks supply equal-and-opposite normal forces when contact is made.
With no additional horizontal forces or torques, neither the blocks nor the cloths slide or topple.
The final configuration is static: A and B drape or sit on top of the block surfaces, and everything stays in place.
